author: By Jack Healy and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Motive in Boulder Shooting Is Still a Mystery, Police Say
description: The gunman used a semiautomatic handgun that is essentially a shortened version of an AR-15-style rifle. He had purchased it legally six days before the attack.
content: BOULDER, Colo. — Investigators searching for answers after the mass shooting in Boulder, Colo., this week still do not know why a gunman shot and killed 10 people at a crowded grocery store, the police chief said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Amanda Gorman’s Poetry United Critics. It’s Dividing Translators.
description: Should a white writer translate a Black poet’s work? A debate in Europe has exposed the lack of diversity in the world of literary translation.
content: Hadija Haruna-Oelker, a Black journalist, has just produced the German translation of Amanda Gorman’s “The Hill We Climb,” the poem about a “skinny Black girl” that for many people was the highlight of President Biden’s inauguration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: Jokes and Pranks Pave the Way For Love
description: Caroline Gholson and Andrew Fallon’s relationship was filled with “gotcha” moments from the start. But, Mr. Fallon’s bedroom proposal made his high jinks next level.
content: Caroline Gholson had often told Andrew Fallon that she wanted him to propose over coffee — in bed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Australia Is Returning to Normal. But Should Everything?
description: From JobSeeker to working from home to … online menus?
content: During a recent trip to a local cafe, I realized with some dismay that the digital ordering system it had starting using during the pandemic was no more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Who Are Gavin Newsom’s Enemies?
description: California’s governor, once one of the most popular in the country, is fighting for his job. Here’s a look at what happened.
content: For Democratic officials aiming at higher office, California’s top political jobs have appeared to be the perfect launchpad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: North Korea’s Arsenal Has Grown Rapidly. Here’s What’s in It.
description: The country has one of the largest standing armies in the world, but much of its equipment is old and obsolete. North Korea has sought to make up for those shortcomings by building nuclear weapons.
content: SEOUL — North Korea test-launched what it called a newly developed tactical guided missile ​on Thursday, violating international sanctions.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Kristen Soltis Anderson
description: The March 26 episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Kristen Soltis Anderson. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Otis
title: How Do You Talk With People Who Don’t Share Your Views?
description: Have you ever successfully changed someone’s mind? Has someone ever convinced you to alter your thinking on a certain issue?
content: How often do you struggle to connect with a loved one who holds a different set of beliefs, values or opinions from you? Has there been a time when you earnestly tried to change someone’s mind about an important issue? Do you think most people are open to the possibility of rethinking their firmly held beliefs? How open are you to changing your own views?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ceylan Yeginsu
title: Want to Go to Europe This Summer? Here Are Your Options
description: For American travelers hoping to head abroad, answers to questions about which countries they can visit and what the future might hold.
content: With the number of people in the United States vaccinated against the coronavirus climbing, Americans are starting to explore their prospects for international travel this summer, a season when Europe is traditionally a big draw.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Veronique Greenwood
title: The Mysterious Molecular Culprit Behind Cold Tooth Pain
description: Researchers figured out how a jolt of discomfort gets from the damaged outside of your tooth to the nerves inside it.
content: There’s nothing quite like the peculiar, bone-jarring reaction of a damaged tooth exposed to something cold: a bite of ice cream, or a cold drink, and suddenly, that sharp, searing feeling, like a needle piercing a nerve.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum and Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Fox News Faces Second Defamation Suit Over Election Coverage
description: Dominion Voting Systems, an election technology company, accused the channel of advancing lies that devastated its reputation and business.
content: Fox News and its powerful owner, Rupert Murdoch, are facing a second major defamation suit over the network’s coverage of the 2020 presidential election, a new front in the growing legal battle over media disinformation and its consequences.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: Before Sister Jean’s Star Turn, an Earlier Loyola Team Cherished Her
description: The Ramblers had a dismal record in 1994-95, the first season Sister Jean Dolores Schmidt was the team chaplain. Now in their 40s, players still find their voices catching when they talk about her.
content: ATLANTA — Joe Estes just wanted to say hello to Sister Jean.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Friday Briefing
description: President Biden’s first news conference.
content: During a question-and-answer session with journalists that lasted more than an hour, President Biden called Republican efforts to limit voting rights “sick” and “un-American,” saying that the party’s own voters viewed actions that make it harder for people to cast ballots as “despicable” attempts to undermine democracy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘Decolonizing the Hunt for Dinosaurs and Other Fossils’
description: In this lesson, students will learn about attempts to make paleontology more inclusive and consider what should happen to artifacts that were stolen or taken by force during colonial rule.
content: Featured Article: “Decolonizing the Hunt for Dinosaurs and Other Fossils” by Asher Elbein
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg and Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: The U.S. will soon have more doses than people eligible or willing to get vaccinated.
content: By the end of July, the U.S. government will have had enough doses to vaccinate the country’s entire population, with 70 million doses to spare. Tens of millions more doses are promised to the U.S. in the months that follow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alisha Haridasani Gupta
title: Misogyny Fuels Violence Against Women. Should It Be a Hate Crime?
description: Experts say the everyday harassment women have learned to put up with — the catcalling and lewd gestures — connects directly with more serious abuses.
content: —  Caroline Criado Perez, author of “Invisible Women: Exposing Data Bias in a World Designed for Men”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norimitsu Onishi
title: France Has ‘Overwhelming’ Responsibility for Rwanda Genocide, Report Says
description: The report, commissioned by President Emmanuel Macron, found that France’s colonial mind-set had blinded it to the atrocity. The authors, though, cleared France of complicity.
content: PARIS — Blinded by its fears of losing influence in Africa and by a colonial view of the continent’s people, France remained close to the “racist, corrupt and violent regime’’ responsible for the 1994 genocide in Rwanda, and bears “serious and overwhelming” responsibilities, according to a report released Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal and Hari Kumar
title: Using Shame, Lending Apps in India Squeeze Billions Out of the Desperate
description: With techniques honed in China, a new breed of company offers expensive loans to people devastated by the pandemic. If they can’t repay, family and friends hear all about it.
content: HYDERABAD, India — The harassing calls began soon after sunrise. Kiran Kumar remained in bed and, for hours, thought about how he was going to end his hostage of a life.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 40 Years of Michael Mann. 11 Great Movie Moments.
description: To celebrate four decades of intense moviemaking, we asked writers to share their favorite scenes from the director’s career.
content: Forty years ago this weekend, Michael Mann released his first feature, “Thief,” which in retrospect contained several signatures of the director’s work, like stories that revolve around mostly lone wolves, told with intricate cutting, artful visuals and unexpected musical choices. We asked 11 writers to look over a career filled with memorable movies and pick out the scenes that still stick with them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Virginia Postrel
title: Women and Men Are Like the Threads of a Woven Fabric
description: The textiles women produced made our civilization what it is.
content: We are all descended from both women and men, culturally as well as biologically. So why do we celebrate Women’s History Month separately in March?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Siegel Bernard
title: Millions are still waiting for stimulus payments. But the I.R.S. is making progress.
description: Tens of millions of people who receive benefits from Social Security or other programs but don’t have to file a tax return are closer to receiving payments.
content: Tens of millions of lower-income Americans are still waiting for their stimulus checks, but there’s been some progress toward getting them paid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Pérez-Peña
title: U.K. School Assailed From 2 Directions Over Muhammad Cartoon
description: A cartoon of the prophet, considered blasphemous by many Muslims, is once again provoking debate and competing accusations of prejudice and extremism.
content: A cartoon of the Prophet Muhammad — this time, its use in a British classroom — is once again stoking anger and national debates about the limits of tolerance, free speech and education.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mona El-Naggar
title: Trains Collide in Egypt, Killing at Least 32
description: Officials said emergency brakes were activated on one train, which was hit by another behind it. The country’s railways have been plagued by poor maintenance and mismanagement.
content: CAIRO — Two trains collided in southern Egypt on Friday, killing at least 32 people and injuring more than 160 in the latest disaster to strike a railway system that has long been plagued by accidents, poor maintenance and mismanagement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: Volkswagen will seek damages from former executives accused in emissions fraud.
description: Volkswagen had been reluctant to publicly accuse former top managers of complicity in the emissions fraud, which has cost Volkswagen tens of billions of euros in fines, settlements and legal fees.
content: Volkswagen said on Friday that it would seek financial compensation from its former chief executive and the former head of the Audi division, accusing them of failing to act after learning that diesel vehicles sold in the United States were fitted with illegal emissions-cheating software.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ligaya Mishan
title: The Growers, Bakers and Beekeepers Embracing the Terroir of American Cities
description: Long celebrated in France, the concept of place-specific tastes is spurring the revitalization of neighborhoods and communities.
content: THE GRAPEVINES RISE at the corner of East 66th Street and Hough Avenue in Cleveland, 14 trim green rows claiming over half a city block — a little less than an acre — beside an abandoned building with boarded-up windows, whose rolling lawn on a summer morning is as lush as Versailles’s. The sky is brilliant and wide above stoplights and swoops of telephone wire. Across the tar-patched street stand storefronts behind scissor gates and a former grocery whose facade half collapsed last May, raining brick on the sidewalk. Down the avenue, the walls of another boarded-up building have been commandeered as an outdoor art gallery, papered over in posters with messages: “I survived the Hough riots”; “Growing your own food is like printing your own money.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Eavis and Lauren Hirsch
title: After Failed I.P.O., WeWork Will Go Public Through a Merger
description: The money-losing office space firm plans to merge with a blank-check company backed by big Wall Street investors.
content: Even though WeWork has long lost billions of dollars, it always found ways to attract huge investments from deep-pocketed investors. Now, less than two years after it was rescued from a collapse, the co-working company has found yet another backer willing to overlook its losses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Liesbeth Stoeffler, 61, Runner Kept Going by Rare Lung Treatment, Dies
description: A machine that acted as an artificial lung kept her eligible for a transplant as she dealt with cystic fibrosis. She went on to compete again in marathons.
content: Liesbeth Stoeffler’s doctors had a bold decision to make in 2009. Ms. Stoeffler was on a ventilator and deeply sedated after cystic fibrosis had destroyed the lungs that had once given her the ability to run and hike.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Parker-Pope
title: ‘How Did You Qualify?’ For the Young and Vaccinated, Rude Questions and Raised Eyebrows
description: Medical privacy has become the latest casualty of vaccination efforts, as friends, co-workers and even total strangers ask intrusive questions about personal health conditions.
content: When Helena Jenkins, 23, recently asked to leave work early for a vaccination appointment, her boss at a Nashville retail store was incredulous.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tina Jordan
title: The Essential Larry McMurtry
description: The Pulitzer Prize-winning novelist and Academy Award-winning screenwriter explored the myths and legacies of the West in his work.
content: Larry McMurtry, who died on Thursday at age 84, left behind a trove of work that explored the myths and legacy of the West. Many of his best books — including “Horseman, Pass By,” “The Last Picture Show,” “Leaving Cheyenne” and “Lonesome Dove” — were made into movies or TV shows that have since eclipsed the original novels. Do yourself a favor and pick them up again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: ‘The Falcon and the Winter Soldier’ Season 1, Episode 2 Recap: Freedom Isn’t Free
description: It’s a big job being asked to symbolize an entire nation’s ideals, as the new Captain America is about to find out. But is he the best person for the job?
content: If you’ve encountered Captain America only in the Marvel movies, it may surprise you to learn that in the comic books, Steve Rogers isn’t the only person who has picked up the shield and called himself (or herself) “Captain America.” There have been dozens of reboots, retcons and alternate universes in Marvel Comics’ publishing history, and along the way over a dozen heroes have donned the red, white and blue. More often than not, the stories about these characters weigh one big issue: What does it take to symbolize an entire nation’s ideals?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Supporters of Gun Control Assail Biden Over Delay on Action
description: After two mass shootings in a week, the president said his next priority would be an infrastructure bill, frustrating those who want to see him put more resources behind gun legislation.
content: WASHINGTON — Supporters of gun control lashed out at President Biden on Friday for suggesting a day earlier that gun legislation would not be his next priority even after two mass shootings in a week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Jackson, Mahima Chablani and Desiree Ibekwe
title: The Forgotten Sense
description: Regaining what the coronavirus took from you.
content: Hi everyone, phew, we made it to Friday. There was some heaviness in our coverage this week — including some of the neurological symptoms of long-Covid and the King Soopers shooting in Colorado. In between, we tried to splice in some brightness: the prospect of widespread vaccination and a nursing home’s first day out of lockdown. To keep the optimism going, we’d love to hear what you’re most looking forward to in a post-vaccination future. Shoot us an email and we might share your update in a future newsletter. (And if you’re still questioning whether a vaccine is for you, take a look at this guide answering your questions about vaccine safety and access.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: On Sports and SPACs
description: Alex Rodriguez isn’t like the other athletes getting into blank-check firms.
content: Professional athletes can sell almost anything, from soda to sneakers to car insurance. But lately they’ve used their star power to sell SPACs, the blank-check acquisition vehicles that have raised more than $90 billion this year. Amid frenzied competition for merger deals, about a fifth of SPACs launched since last year have brought athletes on board in hopes of standing out when pitching to start-ups they hope to take public, Matthew Goldstein and DealBook’s Lauren Hirsch report.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madison Armstrong and Jennifer Carlson
title: We’ve Spent Over a Decade Researching Guns in America. This Is What We Learned.
description: We can find real solutions to gun violence if we recognize the trauma it causes.
content: In the span of a week, two acts of public violence have stolen the lives of 18 people and provided a stark reminder of the mass gun violence that characterized the pre-Covid United States — and that looms with the end of the pandemic. In the first, a gunman, acting within a broader context of anti-Asian misogyny, went to three Atlanta-area massage businesses, taking the lives of eight people. The second, in Boulder, Colo., occurred at a grocery store — one of the few places people still congregate during the pandemic — as some went about their shopping and others eagerly waited to be vaccinated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Talbot
title: A Revolutionary Shoe Design Updated for a New Century
description: Salvatore Ferragamo’s Invisible Sandal was a marvel when it was introduced in 1947. This season, its signature heel is back.
content: Salvatore Ferragamo made his first pair of shoes when he was 9 years old: When his family couldn’t afford to buy white Mary Janes for his sister’s first communion, he borrowed nails, thread and canvas from a local cobbler and stayed up all night making her a pair. By age 12, he was running his own shoe shop in Bonito, a small village east of Naples. About five years later, in 1915, he emigrated to the United States and soon began designing footwear for Hollywood film studios and the director Cecil B. DeMille. Eventually, he counted Mary Pickford, Greta Garbo, Douglas Fairbanks and Rudolph Valentino among his clients.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Jesse Lingard and Tricks of the Light
description: Be patient, West Ham’s David Moyes said when he signed the out-of-favor forward from Manchester United in January. Both are already reaping the rewards.
content: For possibly the first and only time this season, David Moyes was wrong. As the January transfer window drew to a close, his West Ham side had agreed on a deal to sign Jesse Lingard on loan from Manchester United, and Moyes was keen to stave off the Premier League’s proclivity for rushing to judgment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter S. Goodman
title: In Suez Canal, Stuck Ship Is a Warning About Excessive Globalization
description: The shutdown of the vital waterway and its impact on trade underscore the world’s reliance on global supply chains.
content: LONDON — The world got another warning this week about the perils of its heavy reliance on global supply chains. As a single ship ran aground in the Suez Canal, shutting down traffic in both directions, international commerce confronted a monumental traffic jam with potentially grave consequences.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $1.1 Million Homes in California
description: A Tudor Revival bungalow in Los Angeles, a Craftsman house in Oakland and a cottage in Santa Clara.
content: Tucked into a cul-de-sac in the lower Hollywood Hills, this property is within walking distance of the Hollywood Bowl, an amenity the sellers often took advantage of. It is also just off North Highland Avenue, a major artery that takes commuters south to West Hollywood and north to Studio City. Also within walking distance (or a five-minute drive) is the Hollywood and Highland complex, which includes a Metro stop on the downtown-bound Red Line.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: The Psychic Said She’d Never Get Married. (They Eloped.)
description: Jen Glantz and Adam Kossoff eloped on the fourth anniversary of their first meeting. A few weeks before they met a psychic warned that she would never find true love.
content: Jen Glantz, the founder of Bridesmaids for Hire, a company that farms out freelancers to complete bridal tasks that may or may not include zipping into a taffeta dress, had planned two weddings for herself in 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss
title: How a Javits Center Vaccine Nurse Spends Her Sundays
description: ‘This job makes me feel like I’m part of history.’
content: In early January, Nicole Brienza, a recent nursing school graduate, was looking for work. When she found out about the huge vaccination program that was about to open at the Javits Center, she applied immediately. “Within an hour I got a call,” she said. Three days later she was offered a position there. “This job makes me feel like I’m part of history,” said Ms. Brienza, 24, whose first day at Javits was Jan. 17. “It’s a once-in-a-lifetime experience.” She lives with her parents, Carmela and Joe Brienza, and her younger brothers, Joey and Johnny, in Whitestone, Queens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Weekend
description: Put Naoko Takei Moore’s recipe for tsukune miso nabe, a gingery chicken-meatball hot pot, on your must-make list.
content: Good morning. The nation is grieving, has been grieving for more than a year: for those murdered in mass shootings, for those killed by the police, for those lost to Covid in the horrid early months of the pandemic, for those lost over the course of the months that followed, for those lost this week, yesterday, today. It’s overwhelming. It’s exhausting and unceasing. Even as tulips rise and snowdrops bloom, as vaccinations accelerate and people gather in hope, there’s a palpable sadness ingrained in our lives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere and Noah Weiland
title: For Biden, a New Virus Dilemma: How to Handle a Looming Glut of Vaccine
description: As U.S. manufacturers hit their stride, vaccine scarcity will soon turn to plenty as much of the world goes begging. And vaccine makers need answers now about what to do with the coming surplus.
content: WASHINGTON — Biden administration officials are anticipating the supply of coronavirus vaccine to outstrip U.S. demand by mid-May if not sooner, and are grappling with what to do with looming surpluses when vaccine scarcity turns to glut.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill P. Capuzzo
title: Talk Politics? Some Brokers Are Only Too Happy to Do So
description: Some real estate agents seem eager to post their political views on social media. But, especially in the last year, some of those messages veered toward hate speech, leading the industry to sharpen its ethics rules.
content: During election season, Nancy Kowalik, a real estate broker, proudly plants signs for local and national Republican candidates in her front yard and outside her real estate office in Mullica Hill, N.J. Step into that Main Street office and you’re likely to get an earful of Ms. Kowalik’s anti-vaccine and anti-mask views.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steve Inskeep
title: For 50 Years, I Was Denied the Story of My Birth
description: All adoptees deserve better.
content: In 1968, a woman appeared for an interview at the Children’s Bureau, an adoption agency in Indianapolis. She was in her 20s and alone. A caseworker noted her name, which I am withholding for reasons that will become apparent, and her appearance: She was “a very attractive, sweet looking girl,” who seemed “to come from a good background” and was “intelligent.” She had “blue eyes and rather blonde hair,” though the woman said her hair was getting darker over time, like that of her parents.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Nursing Home’s First Day Out of Lockdown
description: Residents in West Virginia shared their feelings about being allowed to mix again after months of isolation.
content: The Good Shepherd Nursing Home in West Virginia lifted its coronavirus lockdown in February.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Correal
title: What the ‘Invisible’ People Cleaning the Subway Want Riders to Know
description: Contract workers hired to help disinfect the New York City subway during the pandemic are asking the M.T.A. to support a job they say goes far beyond wiping down poles.
content: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil MacFarquhar
title: Far-Right Extremists Move From ‘Stop the Steal’ to Stop the Vaccine
description: Extremist organizations are now bashing the safety and efficacy of coronavirus vaccines in an effort to try to undermine the government.
content: Adherents of far-right groups who cluster online have turned repeatedly to one particular website in recent weeks — the federal database showing deaths and adverse reactions nationwide among people who have received Covid-19 vaccinations.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tillie Olsen and the Barriers to Creativity
description: A. O. Scott discusses Olsen’s work, and Wendy Lower talks about “The Ravine: A Family, a Photograph, a Holocaust Massacre Revealed.”
content: A.O. Scott, a critic at large and the co-chief film critic for The Times, returns to the Book Review’s podcast this week to discuss the work of Tillie Olsen, the latest subject in his essay series The Americans, about writers who give a sense of the country’s complex identity. Olsen, who died in 2007 at 94, was known best as the author of “Tell Me a Riddle,” a collection of three short stories and a novella published in 1961. She also wrote rigorous depictions of working-class families, conveying the costs of living for burdened mothers, wives and daughters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Kim
title: Umami Is Often a Flavor Bomb. In This Creamy Pasta, It’s a Balm.
description: A versatile pantry staple in many cuisines, dried seaweed can lend a quiet savoriness to dishes, like this simple asparagus rigatoni.
content: In 1908, the Japanese chemist Kikunae Ikeda discovered that an amino acid called glutamate in kombu, or dried kelp, was responsible for the wonderful savoriness in his wife’s dashi, a stock that forms the basis of many dishes including miso soup, shabu shabu and okonomiyaki.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles, Jon Caramanica and Giovanni Russonello
title: Lil Nas X Makes a Coming-Out Statement, and 9 More New Songs
description: Hear tracks by Taylor Swift, Rod Wave, Dr. Lonnie Smith and Iggy Pop and others.
content: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: Larry McMurtry, Novelist of the American West, Dies at 84
description: In “Lonesome Dove,” “The Last Picture Show” and dozens more novels and screenplays, he offered unromantic depictions of a long mythologized region.
content: Larry McMurtry, a prolific novelist and screenwriter who demythologized the American West with his unromantic depictions of life on the 19th-century frontier and in contemporary small-town Texas, died on Thursday at home in Archer City, Texas. He was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang
title: ‘Insult to the Country’: Hong Kong Targets Art Deemed Critical of China
description: Pro-Beijing lawmakers have called for work by the dissident artist Ai Weiwei to be removed from a new museum, and accused local arts groups of undermining national security.
content: HONG KONG — With its multibillion-dollar price tag and big-name artists, M+, the museum rising on Victoria Harbor, was meant to embody Hong Kong’s ambitions of becoming a global cultural hub. It was to be the city’s first world-class art museum, proof that Hong Kong could do high culture just as well as finance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley, Ronen Bergman, Farnaz Fassihi and Eric Schmitt
title: Israel’s Shadow War With Iran Moves Out to Sea
description: Israel and Iran have fought a clandestine war across the Middle East for years, mainly by land and air. Now ships are under attack in the Mediterranean and Red Seas.
content: JERUSALEM — The sun was rising on the Mediterranean one recent morning when the crew of an Iranian cargo ship heard an explosion. The ship, the Shahr e Kord, was about 50 miles off the coast of Israel, and from the bridge the sailors saw a plume of smoke rising from one of the hundreds of containers stacked on deck.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gillian R. Brassil and Jeré Longman
title: Canada’s Artistic Swimming Coach on Leave Amid Allegations
description: The coach of Canada’s most elite team — slated for the Olympics — will step aside as he awaits the outcome of a disciplinary hearing about allegations of emotional abuse.
content: The head coach of Canada’s national artistic swimming team will take a personal leave pending the results of a disciplinary hearing into whether he created a toxic training environment for athletes, The Canadian Press reported, quoting Canada’s artistic swimming organization.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: NFTs Are Neither Miracles nor Scams
description: People are buying digital items like a tweet and a meme for bonkers amounts of money. Let’s take a step back.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eddie Burkhalter, Richard Fausset, Rick Rojas and Jesus Jiménez
title: After the Tornadoes, Small Towns Grieve for Lost Lives and Wrecked Homes
description: Dozens of tornadoes tore across Alabama and Georgia beginning on Thursday, leaving at least six dead and many neighborhoods in tatters.
content: OHATCHEE, Ala. — The place where one home stood was nothing but cinder blocks and a bald patch of earth. The chicken coop had evaporated, leaving behind a pile of cracked eggs and a loose rooster. Metal siding was knotted around the trunks of trees and the grass was littered with splintered wood, clothes and toys.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Catch up: Jack Dorsey says Twitter played a role in U.S. Capitol riot.
description: Lawmakers grilled the leaders of Facebook, Google and Twitter on Thursday about the connection between online disinformation and the Jan. 6 riot at the Capitol.
content: Lawmakers grilled the leaders of Facebook, Google and Twitter on Thursday about the connection between online disinformation and the Jan. 6 riot at the Capitol.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wendy Lu
title: Overlooked No More: Kitty Cone, Trailblazer of the Disability Rights Movement
description: Shunned in school because of her disability, she devoted her life to the cause, organizing a historic sit-in that led to landmark federal legislation.
content: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: John Edgar Wideman’s Stories Vividly Evoke Life in Pittsburgh and Many Other Places
description: “You Made Me Love You” collects short stories from throughout Wideman’s acclaimed career.
content: Pittsburgh, what a generator of loneliness and tumult. Its predominantly African-American Hill District was the forcing ground of the playwright August Wilson, who paid such tender and respectful attention to lives there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: The Agency at the Center of America’s Tech Fight With China
description: Washington lawmakers, lobbyists and other parties have been vying to influence how the Bureau of Industry and Security, under the Biden administration, will approach a technology relationship with China.
content: WASHINGTON — As tensions between the United States and China escalate, a little-known federal agency is at the center of a debate in the Biden administration about how tough an approach to take when it comes to protecting American technology.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: Drillers Burned Off Gas at a Staggering Rate as Winter Storm Hit Texas
description: Frigid temperatures last month froze pipelines and forced companies to flare vast amounts of planet-warming gases that they suddenly had nowhere to send.
content: As Texas was crippled last month by frigid temperatures that killed more than 100 people and triggered widespread blackouts, drilling companies in the state’s largest oil field were forced to burn off an extraordinary amount of natural gas — on the worst day, an amount that could have powered tens of thousands of homes for at least a year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: The Best Salad Croutons Are Actually Cheese
description: Halloumi, seared until golden, is perfect on a salad of crisp, bitter greens.
content: Baked feta may be having a moment, but it’s got nothing on a slab of halloumi seared until golden, crisp and slightly melted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: U.N.’s Khashoggi Investigator Describes ‘Brazen’ Saudi Threat
description: Agnès Callamard, who wrote of a cover-up in the 2018 killing of the journalist Jamal Khashoggi, called out “bully boy” tactics and intimidation in international diplomacy.
content: A senior Saudi official made a public threat against a United Nations investigator looking into the killing of the journalist Jamal Khashoggi in 2018, according to the investigator, who decried the intimidation and violence she said defenders of human rights faced in carrying out their work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Jeremiah M. Bogert, Jr
title: Vaccines, Georgia, Beverly Cleary: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Seth Meyers Recaps Biden’s First Press Conference
description: The “Late Night” host says the president is at his best “when he’s got the vibe of an old-timer football coach giving his young squad an inspirational halftime speech.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. We’re all stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan
title: New York Theaters Are Dark, but These Windows Light Up With Art
description: The Irish Repertory Theater is streaming poetry readings, and Playwrights Horizons and St. Ann’s Warehouse are showcasing art dealing with race and injustice.
content: Like many cultural organizations, the Irish Repertory Theater in Manhattan has streamed pandemic programming on its website.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Janelle Monáe and Ralph Lauren Make the Case for Clubbing
description: Stella McCartney and Junya Watanabe join in. Rei Kawakubo floats above. Yes, there are still shows going on.
content: The last time Ralph Lauren had a real live fashion show, it was a doozy. That was way back in September 2019, when the world was in a very different place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin
title: $1 Million Raised After Attack on Asian Woman Will Go to Fight Racism, Family Says
description: The woman, Xiao Zhen Xie, 75, was punched by a white man last week. Her family raised money through GoFundMe to pay for her medical expenses. Now, they want to use it to fight anti-Asian racism.
content: After a Chinese grandmother was attacked by a white man in broad daylight in San Francisco last week, she fought back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elliot Ackerman
title: Yes, They Defended the Capitol. But Should They Be Decorated?
description: The military is one of the last institutions in American life without an overt political bias. We need to keep it that way.
content: Ribbons mean a lot in military culture. Earlier this month, the Department of Defense announced that members of the National Guard deployed to Washington, D.C., after the Jan. 6 riot would be awarded a newly created pair of ribbons to wear on their uniforms, a type of decoration typically issued for participation in overseas military campaigns. Hearing the news, I recalled a debate among the Marines I served with about another ribbon, the much-coveted Combat Action Ribbon, awarded to those who have “actively participated in ground or surface combat.” That debate occurred in the summer of 2005, during an emergency deployment to Hurricane Katrina. Three days after the storm hit, the Bush administration ordered our infantry battalion, which had only several months before returned from combat in Falluja, down to New Orleans as part of a patched-together federal response.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Janice McLaughlin, Nun Who Exposed Abuse in Africa, Dies at 79
description: In a life dedicated to social justice, she was jailed in Rhodesia but later returned to a liberated Zimbabwe to help build its school system.
content: Sister Janice McLaughlin, an American nun who was imprisoned by the white minority government in war-torn Rhodesia for exposing atrocities against its Black citizens, then returned to help the new country of Zimbabwe establish an educational system, died on March 7 in the motherhouse of the Maryknoll Sisters of St. Dominic, near Ossining, N.Y. She was 79.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Krauss
title: New in Paperback: ‘Deacon King Kong’ and ‘The Undocumented Americans’
description: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
content: YELLOW BIRD: Oil, Murder, and a Woman’s Search for Justice in Indian Country, by Sierra Crane Murdoch. (Random House, 400 pp., $18.) In this “remarkable first book,” our reviewer, David Treuer, observed, Murdoch brings “the same fanaticism and dignity” that Lissa Yellow Bird brought to her search for a missing oil worker to the “search for and meaning of modern Native America.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: Biden Defines His Underlying Challenge With China: ‘Prove Democracy Works’
description: At his news conference on Thursday, the president provided a revealing look into how he viewed the threat from Beijing.
content: WASHINGTON — At the end of a winding answer on Thursday about competing with China and about his relationship with Xi Jinping, a man he said does not have a democratic “bone in his body,” President Biden offered up a revealing assessment of one of America’s most pressing challenges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Segal
title: The Gambling Company That Had the Best Pandemic Ever
description: Lockdowns helped Britain’s most profitable online betting outfit, bet365, hit the jackpot. For addicted gamblers, it has been a disaster.
content: LONDON — At no point during the soccer game between Stoke City and visiting Watford did anyone say, “Tonight’s match is brought to you by bet365,” one of the world’s largest online gambling companies. No one needed to. It was pretty obvious.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset, Nick Corasaniti and Mark Leibovich
title: Why the Georgia G.O.P.’s Voting Rollbacks Will Hit Black People Hard
description: The state’s new Republican-crafted law is set to restrict voting access in ways that Democrats and voting rights groups say will have an outsize impact on Black voters.
content: After record turnout flipped Georgia blue for the first time in decades, Republicans who control the state Legislature moved swiftly to put in place a raft of new restrictions on voting access, passing a new bill that was signed into law on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Anti-Asian Activity Online, Walking Down the Aisle Alone and Your Brain on Peloton: The Week in Narrated Articles
description: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
content: Take out your headphones, put down your phone and listen to New York Times journalism narrated by the reporters who wrote the story.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Minneapolis Police Investigate Punching of a Black Teenager by an Officer
description: The events were recorded on video by an eyewitness and came as residents had been protesting another teenager’s arrest in connection with what police said was a “violent felony carjacking.”
content: The Minneapolis Police Department has opened an internal affairs investigation after a Black teenager was punched by an officer who appeared to be white, the mayor and the police chief said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Mydans
title: Bretton Sciaroni, Influential American in Cambodia, Dies at 69
description: After losing his White House job because of his role in the Iran-contra scandal, he reinvented himself as a business broker and government adviser in Phnom Penh.
content: Bretton G. Sciaroni, an American lawyer who became a powerful business broker and an adviser to the government in Cambodia after being fired as a White House official when he became embroiled in the Iran-contra scandal, died on March 12 at his home in Phnom Penh, the nation’s capital . He was 69.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Correal
title: What the people cleaning New York City’s subway want passengers to know.
description: Cleaning the New York City subway has always been a dirty job. But when the pandemic hit last spring, it became even more challenging. When Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo ordered that trains be shut down overnight for cleaning, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority turned to contractors to help undertake the monumental task of scouring the trains in the nation’s largest transit system.
content: Cleaning the New York City subway has always been a dirty job. But when the pandemic hit last spring, it became even more challenging. When Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo ordered that trains be shut down overnight for cleaning, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority turned to contractors to help undertake the monumental task of scouring the trains in the nation’s largest transit system.

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: A Yale Psychiatrist’s Tweet About Dershowitz, Her Dismissal, and a Lawsuit
description: The psychiatrist, Bandy X. Lee, said she was let go after the lawyer Alan M. Dershowitz complained to the university. Yale said she violated ethics rules against diagnosing public figures, her lawsuit claims.
content: In July 2019, Alan M. Dershowitz, the lawyer who defended President Donald J. Trump during Mr. Trump’s first impeachment trial, said in an interview that he had a “perfect sex life” with his wife.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Open Mouth
description: What do you think this image is saying?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin, Eileen Sullivan and Sharon LaFraniere
title: At least 34 states are giving all adults vaccine access by mid-April, and more aim to by Biden’s May 1 goal.
description: On Friday, Kansas, Minnesota and South Carolina said those 16 years and older would be eligible next week, and New Jersey said people 55 and older would be eligible on April 5.
content: States are racing to vaccinate as many people as possible as the United States’ coronavirus infection curve continues its plateau for a third week at more than 55,000 new cases per day, a level that health experts warn could rapidly escalate into a new wave.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes
title: Pompeo meets with Iowa voters, laying the groundwork for a possible presidential campaign.
description: The former secretary of state became the first big-name Republican to meet with voters in Iowa this year.
content: If there was ever any doubt of Mike Pompeo’s political ambitions, the former secretary of state put them to rest on Friday by becoming the first big-name Republican to meet with voters in Iowa this year and lay the groundwork for a possible presidential campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: N.C.A.A. Acknowledges $13.5 Million Budget Gap Between Men’s and Women’s Tournaments
description: Financial details revealed publicly for the first time show that the N.C.A.A.’s budget for the men’s tournament was nearly double that of the women’s tournament in 2019.
content: The N.C.A.A. budgeted nearly double for its men’s basketball tournament in 2019 than what it planned for its women’s competition, a $13.5 million gap that will assuredly drive questions about the organization’s commitment to gender equity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edmund Lee
title: ViacomCBS stock tanks, losing more than half its value in less than a week.
description: Before this week’s meltdown, ViacomCBS had actually been on a bit of a tear, rising nearly tenfold in the past 12 months.
content: Shares of ViacomCBS, the media goliath led by Shari Redstone, took a nosedive this week, with the company losing more than half of its market value in just four days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessie McNellis
title: If I Expect It to End, Will It Hurt Less?
description: I kept telling myself not to believe in him. And yet, believe I did.
content: It started with a Facebook message from a boy I had known peripherally in elementary school lunchrooms, passing through the halls of our high school, and — the main event — seventh grade dance class.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: Why Testing Still Matters
description: With case numbers still high, coronavirus testing remains essential, experts say, but the goals and approach will change as vaccines roll out.
content: Last May, the city of Los Angeles turned a fabled baseball park into a mass testing site for the coronavirus. At its peak, Dodger Stadium was testing 16,000 people a day for the virus, making it the biggest testing site in the world, said Dr. Clemens Hong, who oversees coronavirus testing in Los Angeles County.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter
title: National Book Critics Circle Names 2020 Award Winners
description: A novel about Shakespeare’s son, nonfiction about a slave rebellion in Jamaica and an essay collection exploring Asian-American identity were among this year’s winners.
content: “Hamnet,” a novel by Maggie O’Farrell that imagines the death of Shakespeare’s 11-year-old son during the bubonic plague, won the National Book Critics Circle Award for fiction on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Scientists plan to track possible virus spread in vaccinated U.S. college students.
description: More than 12,000 students are being recruited at more than 20 universities across the country.
content: Can people immunized against the coronavirus still spread it to others? A new study will attempt to answer the question by tracking infections in vaccinated college students and their close contacts, researchers announced on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farah Stockman
title: The County Where Cops Call the Shots
description: Fiscal conservatives and liberal activists both want to curb the power of police unions in Suffolk County. Can they do it?
content: SMITHTOWN, N.Y. — Rob Trotta, a cranky Republican county legislator on Long Island who worked as a cop for 25 years, might be the unlikeliest voice for police reform in America. He’s full of praise for the rank and file. The phrase “defund the police” makes his skin crawl. When he talks about race, he sounds like he’s stuck in the 1980s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Caron
title: Covid Stole Your Sense of Smell? Try Physical Therapy for Your Nose.
description: Doctors are recommending smell training for patients with lingering olfactory problems.
content: When Laura Drager contracted Covid-19 in July, it was as though someone had suddenly muted her olfactory system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: The Social Justice Purge at Idaho Colleges
description: Republican lawmakers try to cancel diversity programs.
content: Last month, I wrote that right-wing legislatures trying to ban critical race theory from public schools and institutions were a far more direct threat to free speech than what’s often called cancel culture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: Two History Buffs Wed Past to Future
description: Daniel West, a venture investor, and Isabel Eberstadt, a singer/songwriter, appreciate the lessons of history.
content: Daniel West, a history buff, was asked what era he would have preferred living in with his wife, Isabel Eberstadt, if given the opportunity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock and The New York Times
title: Beaten, Cuffed, Hauled Away: When Myanmar’s Military Comes Knocking
description: Security forces have responded to protests with increasing ruthlessness, shooting people in the streets, raiding homes and arbitrarily carrying out beatings and arrests.
content: When the police and soldiers arrived in the middle of the night, they fired their guns into the air, threw stones through the windows and threatened to drive a car through the front door if no one opened it. U Shwe Win and his family were asleep. It was 2:30 a.m.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marisa Ingemi
title: When Iowa Faces UConn, All Eyes Will Be on Freshman Stars
description: Iowa’s Caitlin Clark and Connecticut’s Paige Bueckers, among the nation’s top players, will face each other for the first time in college.
content: The next chapter in great athlete duels begins on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abby Ellin
title: This Jewelry Designer Got the Diamond She Had in Mind
description: Adina Kamkhatchi knew after the first cup of coffee with Isaac Mizrahi there would be many more to come.
content: Adina Kamkhatchi and Isaac Mizrahi should have met years ago. Their lives were entwined; they just didn’t know it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: The Covid Testing Slump
description: Covid-19 testing is on the decline. That’s a problem.
content: A few weeks ago, Citigroup began providing at-home Covid-19 testing kits to many of its workers in Chicago and New York. Each kit includes a nasal swab, a paper strip and a liquid solution, and people get a result within minutes. “It looks a little like a pregnancy test,” Dr. Lori Zimmerman, Citigroup’s medical director, told me.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Sullivan
title: Summer Camps See Rebound in Interest
description: After resisting in 2020, many parents see an antidote to a school year when their children have been glued to a computer screen.
content: The pandemic wreaked havoc on summer camps last year, as they struggled to navigate conflicting guidance on how to keep campers safe. In many cases, it didn’t matter what the camps did: Most parents concluded that the only way to keep their children safe was to keep them at home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Michael Bennett, Small-Town Doctor Who Pushed for Masks, Dies at 52
description: His death leaves only one family physician in Greenfield, Mo. He died of complications of Covid-19.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Russeth
title: How Do You Stage a Global Art Show Now? In South Korea, Curators Press On.
description: The Gwangju Biennale, on tap for April 1, is the most closely watched art event in Asia.
content: GWANGJU, South Korea — One warm February morning, the curator Defne Ayas bounded up a steep, sylvan path toward a cemetery in this city of 1.5 million as she discussed shamanic practices, resistance movements and other aspects of the area’s history that are themes in the art exhibition she was finalizing nearby.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein and Lauren Hirsch
title: Athletes Pitch Wall Street’s Hot New Toy, but Not Just to Their Fans
description: Super Bowl winners, N.B.A. greats and tennis royalty are tied up with blank-check companies. That can help SPACs sell themselves to start-up targets in an increasingly competitive landscape.
content: Madison Avenue has long known that athletes can sell almost anything. From soda to sneakers to car insurance, consumers eagerly snap up whatever their favorite sweat-drenched star is pitching.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: ‘Kid 90’ and the Days When Even Wild TV Teens Had Privacy
description: A documentary from Soleil Moon Frye, star of “Punky Brewster,” and a reunion of “The Real World” remind us that Gen X didn’t curate themselves for mass consumption.
content: Sometimes I remember the clunky devices of my youth — the boxy Polaroid cameras, the bricklike car phones, the shrill answering machines, the pagers that could be made to spell an angular, all-caps “BOOBS.” This was the personal tech of the early-to-mid-1990s, in the years before AOL Instant Messenger provided an internet on-ramp, which means it was pretty much the last time an American teenager could behave with some expectation of privacy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane and Pranshu Verma
title: Buttigieg asks Congress for ‘generational investment’ in infrastructure as Democrats mull how to draw Republican support.
description: Pete Buttigieg, the transportation secretary, urged Congress on Thursday to make a “generational investment” to improve the nation’s transit and water systems and address climate change and racial inequities, as Democrats began laying the groundwork to pass sweeping infrastructure proposals that could cost $3 trillion to $4 trillion.
content: Pete Buttigieg, the transportation secretary, urged Congress on Thursday to make a “generational investment” to improve the nation’s transit and water systems and address climate change and racial inequities, as Democrats began laying the groundwork to pass sweeping infrastructure proposals that could cost $3 trillion to $4 trillion.

author: By James Gorman and Julian E. Barnes
title: The C.D.C.’s ex-director offers no evidence in favoring speculation that the coronavirus originated in a lab.
description: It is a theory decried by many scientists and rejected as “extremely unlikely” by at least one World Health Organization international expert. The former official, Dr. Robert Redfield emphasized that it was his opinion.
content: The former director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said in a CNN clip on Friday that he favored a theory, decried by many scientists and rejected as “extremely unlikely” by at least one World Health Organization international expert, that the coronavirus escaped from a lab in Wuhan. The former official, Dr. Robert Redfield, offered no evidence and emphasized that it was his opinion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gillian R. Brassil
title: Photos of the N.C.A.A. Tournament, Then and Now
description: This March, closed arenas mean the madness and the intensity of the N.C.A.A. basketball tournaments is on the court, and not in the stands.
content: The nation’s celebration of college basketball has been a rite of spring for decades, a phenomenon that fans could not imagine a March without — until last year, when a catastrophic pandemic had started to claim the lives of millions around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Morris Dickstein, Critic and Cultural Historian, Dies at 81
description: He had a passion for reading, and for writing about what he was reading. “Criticism,” he once said, “plays a very important role in keeping people honest.”
content: Morris Dickstein, a literary critic, cultural historian and City University of New York professor who was among the last of the first generation of Jewish public intellectuals reared on the Lower East Side, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 81.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Winnipeg’s New Showcase and Meeting Place for Inuit Art and Artists
description: A new museum for the Winnipeg Art Gallery’s leading collection of Inuit art opens on Saturday in a project shaped by Inuit.
content: Winnipeg sits far from the territory of the Inuit. But the Winnipeg Art Gallery has long been the leading collector of their art.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti and Reid J. Epstein
title: Georgia Law Kicks Off Partisan Battle Over Voting Rights
description: Civil rights groups quickly challenged a new law placing restrictions on voting, while President Biden denounced it as “Jim Crow.” Republicans in other states are determined to follow suit with their own measures.
content: The fight over voting rights is emerging as one of the defining conflicts of the Biden era, and Georgia fired the opening shot with a set of new restrictions underscoring the political, legal and financial clashes that will influence whether Republicans retake Congress and the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Pitchers Are Hitting Again, So Injuries Will Follow
description: Players and owners want the designated hitter. Agents like Scott Boras think it is a safety issue. But after experimenting with a universal D.H. last year, N.L. pitchers will bat again — for now.
content: The good news is that there will be a baseball season. The pandemic jeopardized and then truncated last year’s schedule. Next year is an open question, because the collective bargaining agreement between the players and the owners expires Dec. 1. But the coronavirus has largely stayed away from spring training camps, and opening day for the 2021 season is nearly here.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Bond vigilantes are signaling that fiscal deficits may be getting out of hand.
description: Yields on 10-year Treasury notes have risen sharply in recent weeks, a sign that traders are taking the inflation threat more seriously. And if the trend continues, it would put bond investors on a collision course with the Biden administration, which wants to spend trillions more on infrastructure, education and other programs.

author: By Julian E. Barnes, Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Eric Schmitt
title: Officials Try to Sway Biden Using Intelligence on Potential for Taliban Takeover of Afghanistan
description: If U.S. troops leave before any deal between the Taliban and the Afghan government, the militant group will take over much of the country, an intelligence assessment predicted.
content: WASHINGTON — As President Biden signaled this week that he would let a May 1 deadline pass without withdrawing American troops from Afghanistan, some officials are using an intelligence assessment to argue for prolonging the military mission there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: They Broke Up Four Times. Now They’re Married.
description: In the decade they have known each other, Heather Hwalek and Taylor Washburn were used to being apart, and breaking up.
content: Long distance has been a way of life for Heather Hwalek and Taylor Washburn, who have spent more days apart than together, since meeting a decade ago at Yale.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: A Boat Snarled Traffic. No, Not That Boat.
description: The 38-foot boat broke loose from its trailer on Thursday, blocking Florida highway traffic for several hours. While inconvenient, it wasn’t the week’s biggest ship-related bottleneck.
content: A “considerably large boat” blocked traffic on a Florida highway for several hours after it fell on the roadway on Thursday night, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: When Can We Make Out With Strangers Again?
description: And other questions about post-vaccination life for younger adults.
content: A slew of new ads show sloppy kisses. Air travel is ticking back up. And impending vaccination can seem like a ticket back to normalcy for 20-somethings in the United States, many of whom feel desperate to get back to their 2019 social lives. Cramped parties. Strobe-lit dance floors. The ability to spontaneously text a friend: Want to grab a drink?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: California’s Next Vaccine Eligibility Expansion
description: Friday: Gov. Gavin Newsom announced on Thursday that all adults will be eligible for the vaccine by April 15.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nelson D. Schwartz
title: Fear of Inflation Finds a Foothold in the Bond Market
description: There is little evidence for a big jump in prices, but some economists and bond investors fear President Biden’s policies could lead to inflation.
content: The so-called bond vigilantes may be back, 30 years after they led a sell-off in Treasury securities over the prospect of higher government spending by a new Democratic administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: U.K. Government, Sensing an Opportunity, Wraps Itself in the Flag
description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson and his Conservative allies have seized on a dispute over ostentatious displays of the Union Jack as a way to keep opponents on the defensive.
content: LONDON — It started last week when the host of the BBC’s morning show mocked a cabinet minister, Robert Jenrick, for the Union Jack hanging conspicuously behind him, next to a portrait of Queen Elizabeth II. The flag, the host cracked, was not “up to standard-size government interview measurements.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: A Top G.O.P. Pollster on Trump 2024, QAnon and What Republicans Really Want
description: Kristen Soltis Anderson has done some of the most in-depth surveys of the party’s voters to date. Her findings are unnerving.
content: In the aftermath of the Capitol attack, the polling firm Echelon Insights decided to ask voters a simple question: Do they think the goal of politics is more about “enacting good public policy” or “ensuring the country’s survival as we know it?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter S. Goodman and Stanley Reed
title: With Suez Canal Blocked, Shippers Begin End Run Around a Trade Artery
description: The most common option for ships trying to avoid the logjam is to reroute themselves around Africa’s Cape of Good Hope.
content: As the world absorbed the reality that the Suez Canal will almost certainly remain blocked for at least several more days, hundreds of ships stuck at both ends of the channel on Friday began contemplating a far more expensive alternative: forsaking the channel and heading the long way around Africa.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: New Zealand Approves Paid Leave for Couples After Miscarriage or Stillbirth
description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, March 26, 2021.
content: “You get three days’ paid leave, maybe you bury your baby or you have a service, and then you go back to work, and you carry on — and then what? That’s my concern.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth La Ferla
title: Seashell Art and Rock Gardens
description: How Alina Cho, Colby Mugrabi and Dustin Yellin are navigating the pandemic.
content: With the New York charity circuit on hiatus, here is how some philanthropists and society figures are spending their time and resources during the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tina Jordan
title: When Edith Wharton Graced the Cover of the Book Review
description: The first time a photo appeared on the Book Review’s front it was of the author whose work was then blazing through New York society.
content: “Our portrait of Edith Wharton, whose serial novel in Scribner’s, ‘The House of Mirth,’ is so eagerly discussed this summer … is the first portrait printed in The New York Times Book Review in eight years or more,” the editors wrote in the Aug. 12, 1905 issue. content: On Thursday, The New York Times published an article about a new paper that found that farmed fish were being fed a more vegetarian diet, lessening the environmental harm of aquaculture. After the article was published, The Times learned that the lead author of the paper, Rosamond Naylor, serves as a member of the Forest Protection Advisory panel at Cargill Corp., which sells salmon feed. Her role was not disclosed in the ethics declaration that accompanied the paper in Nature, the scientific journal in which it was published. Dr. Naylor has since confirmed her role on the Cargill panel and said she has not taken any monetary compensation from the company. She said she had donated an honorarium that was offered to the Cargill Foundation.
